title: What will Gallup report President Trump's net approval rating to be on 28 April 2017?
preds: His approval rating went up and is now comfortably in the range.  He would have to do something pretty terrible for this to change.
Who wants to bet that this rating will tank soon after April 28th?
Today, only -9. Yesterday, -17.  High volatility. Following @Dsarin.
Original hypothesis turned out to be correct, but the net approval rating was straddled with uncertainty until the end. Updating to match actual result.

I think the result that counts is tomorrow's  - but given the -9 rating today, it is more likely that the final count will be above -15. (Although the count did move a lot - from -15 to -9 - between yesterday and today.

Well, I got slammed on this one. I may have overlooked how (more) people have come to appreciate the way Trump says whatever pops in his head. For example yesterday, he said he didn't realize how hard this job would be, he thought it would be easier than his old job but it turns out, it's more work. I suppose it reveals a certain unpolished politician regardless of the calamities associated with his comments. This question has certainly been a wild ride.

-9! I guess that "tax cut" will win you points every time, no matter who says it, or how likely the cuts will materialize, or if they'll be for one's benefit or for some other party that least needs them.

Trump voters are remaining loyal, and apparently remaining uninformed about the U.S. investigations into activities by Russian intelligence. Related news articles and OSINT below: “Only 28% of Trump voters believe Russia tried to influence the 2016 election,” Business Insider, April 26, http://www.businessinsider.com/only-28-of-trump-voters-believe-russia-tried-to-influence-the-2016-election-2017-4 “Top Pentagon watchdog launches investigation into money that Michael Flynn received from foreign groups,” Washington Post, April 27, https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/checkpoint/wp/2017/04/27/top-pentagon-watchdog-launches-investigation-into-money-that-mike-flynn-received-from-foreign-groups/?utm_term=.b0f7f6fe101e “Carl Bernstein: Flynn is ‘central to what the FBI believes is cover-up,’” The Hill, April 26, http://thehill.com/blogs/blog-briefing-room/news/330612-carl-bernstein-flynn-is-central-to-what-fbi-believes-is-cover “The 4 Russia investigations in Congress, explained,” CNN, April 25, http://www.cnn.com/2017/04/25/politics/congress-russia-investigations “A former top NSA lawyer is joining the Senate's Trump-Russia probe,” Business Insider, April 26, http://www.businessinsider.com/april-doss-will-join-senate-intelligence-committee-russia-investigation-2017-4 “Carter Page: 'I've been the victim of the one of the most horrendous civil rights violations,'” CNN, April 26, http://www.cnn.com/2017/04/27/politics/carter-page-civil-rights-violations-cnntv
It's simple math now. There were 41 days when the poll went down and 52 days where it stayed the same or went up.

(no change) Not to quibble too much with the question wording, but does "on 28 April 2017" mean what is available on the link at midnight 28 April (UTC would be nice in the future) or when Gallup reports they have data for the three days that includes 28 April? A common sense understanding would be the latter. OTOH the question closes on 28 April at 11:59 PM (and typically the latest data included would be for 27 April).

So far, the Gallup polls of DJT's job approval have been somewhat stable around -11, with some outliers (like -24 or +1) at times). Now, Above +15 I think we can safely rule out, (especially since the closing date is tomorrow). The ditches that have been dug in the political war of 2016 are quite deep, and it doesn't look as if people will swing around to Trump if they have been critics before. So, that only leaves one other option: Former supporters who now report not being happy with him. Now here is where there is potential for futher downward trend. But the closing date is tomorrow, and it is unlikely that the values will have changed strongly. Therefore, I simply took how many Gallup polls showed below 15 and divided by the total number of polls, and you get few cases where we would be lower than -15. It is likely that the polls will show somewhere around -14 to -8, with a small chance of showing something else.

The net approval rate on the last 4 days has been: -14, -14, -15, -17. All very close to the limit of -15. It could go either way so the forecast is around 50/50. Not much of a forecast, but there it is. I give a slight edge to "Below -15" because the trend is downward, and because the budget proposal leaves out the financing of the Mexican wall. This could frustrate some of his supporters.
Given his current net is -17, and that the final is only two days away, it is likely to not change that much, certainly with no chance of going to a positive score.

(no change) Why did I start this? The flurry of generalizations and form over substance initiatives probably won't move this poll back into the middle bucket before the end date, but who knows. I was very heavily vested in the below bucket so it won't matter much.
Overcorrection because I truly expected the middle bucket to be lenient. Aside: Brier scores should probably be penalized for gaming as such.

Can't deny that DT keeps things interesting - suspense until the last day! Or GJO was lucky in picking the thresholds for the buckets. 
In any event, health care legislation news doesn't seem to be helping, while the tax cut proposal seems too confusing for  the general public. May be the North Korea briefing will tip the scale.

If this gets publicized on TV news, this really gets under people's skin. As if generating more news about Obamacare weren't enough to make people feel negative (regardless of which side you're on)... but now this? Puts more salt in the wounds. http://www.politico.com/story/2017/04/26/new-obamacare-repeal-plan-republicans-trump-237625 As top conservative groups and lawmakers declared their support for the revised measure, however, a new problem arose that could slow progress. A provision in the proposal appeared to exempt members of Congress and their aides from weakened regulations that states would be allowed to adopt. 170426-kevin-brady-ap-1160.jpg
Obamacare repeal's exception for Congress stokes charges of hypocrisy
By JENNIFER HABERKORN Democrats seized on the language, arguing that Republicans were trying to shield themselves from their own legislation. The Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee even planned a rapid-fire digital ad campaign highlighting the provision as Republicans were grappling with the details. “It should be no surprise that TrumpCare has gotten so terrible that Republicans have resorted to exempting themselves and their families from the pain it inflicts," said Drew Hammill, spokesman for House Democratic leader Nancy Pelosi. "Speaker Ryan and Congressional Republicans promised that Americans with pre-existing conditions would be protected, but it turns out they were only talking about themselves.”

Trump continues to torture us by hovering around -15%.  He has negative momentum in the poll, but the tax plan reveal today may turn this around, or maybe not.  This is a toss-up, with today's bias a little negative.  Tomorrow...
A tax reform for business is not going to sit well with his base. Waffling on the wall as he is now... Even worse for his ratings.

I noticed that since April 4, Trump's favorability landed below 15 on just two occasions: April 14 and today at -17. That's 2 out of 21 measurements -- 10%.  The trend smoothes of course which may predict it going back up a point or two.  However, my original notion months ago was that the news about Trump would get more intense and more attention in the final week covering the 100 days. Although in Trump's case, the 100 days has pretty much been all about him the whole time. 
I don't think the tax cut for corporations is going to help even if people believe what he promises anymore. Especially when he uses terms like HUGE and MASSIVE.. sends up a red flag right away. However, the final poll that will decide this question is on Friday and we won't see one tomorrow because there is a lag-- one update every 2 days.  Gallup features two relevant measures:
45% say Trump keeps his promises, down from 62% in February
President loses ground on five other key characteristics http://www.gallup.com/poll/208685/majority-say-wealthy-americans-corporations-taxed-little More than six in 10 say corporations, upper-income Americans pay too little
Views that middle-income earners pay too much have increased
14% say lower-income pay too little; down from high of 24% five years ago I think people are weary of all the promises and he hasn't much to show for the first 100 days but alot of Executive orders-- key ones being struck down by the courts including the latest one on sanctuary cities. That spells loser-- a label he just can't stand but one if which he set himself up for being judged on those terms. I'm taking a risk but going back to my first prediction.
Updating from 45/55/0. At -17 today. Freaking called it with the healthcare thing! (It was gonna drive his approval down)

-17 with two days to go. Trump has been trending lower over the past week, but is still right around the -15 threshold.  Not sure what precipitated the most recent decline. Perhaps what I interpreted as a lack of an impact from the Syrian bombing and North Korean posturing was instead a temporary stabilization?  Today's announcement of Trump's tax plan is a big wildcard - public reception to the plan might have a significant effect on the approval numbers, one way or another, even while somewhat muted by the three-day rolling average.

Dropped from minus 15 to minus 17 between 24 and 25 April, hence adjusting to 40/60 from 25/75. Will have to monitor this every day, though ultimately the only number that matters will be the one for the 28th.
Two days to go and the 3-day average is -15 exactly, with the trend being toward widening.

Recent polls indicate most people who voted for Trump feel he's doing a good job, despite the investigations into Russian intelligence activities related to people on the Trump team. At the same time, 73 percent of Americans want an independent investigation into these matters, according to recent polls. Because the deadline for this GJ question is April 28, I'm raising my probability estimate of approval for Trump.  However, important witnesses like former acting AG Sally Yates and former DNI James Clapper (our "ex-boss" via IARPA/Good Judgment Project) are scheduled to testify before a congressional panel in the first week of May. Trump's approval could sink after that. Related OSINT in the news: “No sign probes into Russia, Trump campaign will die down,” Associated Press on Austin American- Statesman, April 25, http://www.statesman.com/news/sign-probes-into-russia-trump-campaign-will-die-down/bzix6oZhal03mR8xXdCvHK/ “Lawmakers: Former Trump Security Adviser May Have Broken US Law,” Voice of America, April 25, https://www.voanews.com/a/lawmakers-say-trumps-former-security-advisor-may-have-broken-law/3824989.html “Lawmakers say Flynn did not disclose lobbying and payments from Turkey and Russia,” Los Angeles Times, April 25, http://www.latimes.com/nation/la-na-flynn-lobbying-20170425-story.html “Flynn’s Turkish lobbying linked to Russia,” Politico, April 25, http://www.politico.com/story/2017/04/25/michael-flynn-turkey-russia-237550 “White House blocks Flynn document request,” BBC News, April 25, http://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-39710527 “Poll: 73% Back Independent Probe of Russian Election Interference,” NBC News, April 24, http://www.nbcnews.com/politics/first-read/poll-73-back-independent-probe-russian-election-interference-n750161 “Senate Judiciary sets date for Yates, Clapper testimony on Russia,” Politico, April 25, http://www.politico.com/story/2017/04/25/sally-yates-james-clapper-russia-testimony-schedule-237568

It's approaching heart-in-mouth time. On the one hand, the approval rating has been below minus 15 just once between 04 and 24 April (though 9 times in the 29 days from 27 March). On the other hand, it has been -14,-14 and -15 for the last three days, whereas there has been a change of minus 1 or more on 13 of the 29 days since 27 March.
It's already at -15, it would have to IMPROVE.
Today it's -15, could possible stagnate or fall even lower
A tax cut proposal unveiled tomorrow may help DT, but as of today he is at -15 exactly...

I stand by my calculations with two changes, one a statistical change as this forecast come to its conclusion and one an error correction (I'll call it backwardation). It seems likely as April 28 is a scant four days away that Trump likely ends up "between the 15's." His net approval rating average for the month of April is -12.9, (overall it's -7.9) so while close to the Below - 15 threshold its not quite there. The 3 days he was below -15 in April were the first three days of the month. With that said its not a slam-dunk if his approval ratings fall 2 more points or disapproval increases more than 2 points (or some combination where the net approval declines 2 more points then the Below -15 probability camp wins. I don't see any trend through April as Trump's approval and disapproval ratings hover at just over 40 and 53 respectively. 
One standard deviation to the left of the mean puts the net approval number near -18 while +2 standard deviations from the mean puts the net approval rating at less than +12, this effectively eliminates Above +15 as a viable ending net approval number.
Regarding the flip from the prior forecasts from a 16% chance above +15 to a 15% chance below -15 was due to reversing the three-day rolling average daily numbers from the Gallup daily tracking chart into their spreadsheet columns, approval numbers were transcribed to the disapproval column - rookie mistake!!....
Updating from 40/60/0. At -14 on Sat & Sun, with healthcare & tons more to debate over the week.
Adjusting. Trump's been tweeting again. Should have probably reduced confidence all along.
He's now at -14% again.  Seriously Trump?  You're making this so hard to predict.
This is comical. Trump's ratings are higgly-piggly. Where will they go next?

Updating from 35/65/0. There are promises of more healthcare debate next week --- the single thing that delivered the biggest hit to Trump's approval rate so far, driving him into -20 territory. Budget talks are also scheduled, with a possibility of govt shutdown (on 28 April), and one major issue being "are we going to build, and who is going to pay for, the Mexican wall".  Becoming clear that Mexico will not pay for it in any straightforward way; if that fact gets incorporated into a budget, I wonder if Trump approval will decline among his supporters.
At a nice -10% approval rating, he would have to screw it up badly for this to drop.

In the last 14 days only on 2 days the net score was under -15%, and on both occasions only just. I have the impression that his twittering has gone down significantly and this calms down both his supporters (stable at 42 +- 1) and his detractors (stable at 51 +- 1) .

Information about the U.S. investigations seems to be emerging at a brisk pace. These accumulating reports could affect Trump's approval rating before April 28. Related OSINT in news reports seems to include some relevant information “WATCH: Carter Page confronts CNN report that Russia tried to use him to infiltrate Trump campaign,” Salon, April 22, http://www.salon.com/2017/04/22/carter-page-confronts-cnn-report-that-russia-tried-to-use-him-to-infiltrate-trump-campaign/ Mr. Page seems to be using the tried-and-true methods 1) Deny. 2) Change the narrative. 3) Counterattack. “Reuters: Think Tank Linked To Putin Distributed Plans to Influence U.S. Election,” Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, April 20, https://www.rferl.org/a/russia-reuters-report-influence-u-s-election-influence-putin/28440730.html “Sources: Russia tried to use Trump advisers to infiltrate campaign,” CNN, April 21, http://www.cnn.com/2017/04/21/politics/russia-trump-campaign-advisers-infiltrate And on the issue of sanctions against Russia, an important topic in the current U.S. counterintelligence investigations ... “Trump denies Exxon permission to drill for oil in Russia,” CNN Money, April 21, http://money.cnn.com/2017/04/21/news/companies/trump-exxon-russia-sanctions “U.S. Rejects Exxon Mobil Bid for Waiver on Russia Sanctions,” New York Times, April 21, https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/21/business/energy-environment/treasury-exxon-mobil-sanctions-waiver.html?_r=0 It seems somewhat odd that Exxon Mobil would ask the Trump administration to waive sanctions for oil deals at this time. Certainly Exxon Mobil would know that this would be an unwise time to make this request, due to various tensions and investigations.  However, it does give the Trump administration an opportunity to deny the request – which could be helpful politically and legally with regard to ongoing U.S. counterintelligence investigations.
The "massive tax cut" to be unveiled next week (see Bloomberg) may offset most of the criticism associated with a possible and messy government shutdown.

Even if there is a government shutdown I don't think it has time to work its way into the approval rating. Other than that its going to take a truly momentous event  in the next 7 days for him to end up in the -15 bracket.
In the two weeks from 06 to 19 April, net approval has been below minus 15 just once (-16% on 14 April), and has improved each day since then.
Today, 4/20/17, we are seeing his standing at 43/50, a -7% difference.......
538 trend is for narrowing of the gap.
With Trump taking steps to having accomplished something more than Gorsuch's approval during his first 100 Days, I suspect he'll keep his net rating in the middle range.  Adjusting accordingly.
Trump is enjoying his military maneuvers while not talking about taking away people's healthcare which is significantly helping his ratings.
Trump's popularity has increased lately. I don't believe it can swing back till the end of month.

The last week will be tumultuous, but Trump's rating can afford a moderate decline and still remain in the middle bucket. The pressure to pass anything on health care should yield some result. The government shutdown possibility is a major unpredictable, however.

Updating from 40/60/0. Approval has been climbing for a week, reached -7 yesterday. Biggest impacts to his approval seem to have been the Flynn resignation and the AHCA debacle. Seems like the House is poised to try something in the healthcare domain again next week [1]. I honestly don't know how people will respond. My simple mental model of the situation is: for almost any proposal Republicans put forward, left-leaning media will report it as bad, and conservative media will report it as good. But then what swung the approval ratings so low last time? In the simple model, liberals already thought Trump was bad, and conservatives already thought he was good (roughly speaking). So the simple model is failing to account for some big effect. Independents? My experience with humans makes me doubt quite strongly that any significant number of them is actually reading the proposed bills and thinking through the consequences. Even if it's just one week to go, media is already reporting that a new healthcare-related effort is happening in the House. If it's a replay of the first time around, approval that week will almost certainly be below -15. But maybe they learned their lesson and will do it differently this time? I just don't know WHAT could be done differently. [1] http://www.politico.com/story/2017/04/20/obamacare-repeal-republicans-new-deal-237397

Not sure what's precipitating this rather dramatic swing in approval rating (delayed positive reaction from the Syrian strikes and aggressive NK posturing?) but with roughly a week to go, it's time to be fairly sensitive to the daily results (-7 today).

One week to go to deadline on this question. Information about Trump-Russia connections has been emerging somewhat frequently. Will that information reach a tipping point in public opinion before April 28? Seems to depend on investigators, including the U.S. IC, international intelligence professionals, and the U.S. and international news media investigative teams. Related OSINT in the news: “Exclusive: Putin-linked think tank drew up plan to sway 2016 U.S. election – documents,” Reuters news service, April 19, http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-russia-election-exclusive-idUSKBN17L2N3 “Trump Adviser’s Visit to Moscow Sent the F.B.I. Digging,” New York Times, April 19, https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/19/us/politics/carter-page-russia-trump.html?_r=1 “FBI used dossier allegations to bolster Trump-Russia investigation,” CNN, April 17, http://www.cnn.com/2017/04/18/politics/fbi-dossier-carter-page-donald-trump-russia-investigation “Exxon Mobil Seeks U.S. Sanctions Waiver for Oil Project in Russia,” New York Times, April 19, https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/19/business/energy-environment/exxon-mobil-russia-sanctions-waiver-oil.html

The President has maintained his net approval rating between -15 and +15% inclusive throughout the major events surrounding his first 100 days in office. Barring any major domestic/foreign policy crises or major legislation, I believe the President will maintain the same net approval rating.

Correction to my prior forecasts! I corrected two errors in my spreadsheet calculations (measure twice, cut once, right?). Looking at the hopefully now correct numbers to date as we near the 100 day mark, Trump's net approval has been between -15 and +15 about 83% of the time, below -15 about 1% of the time and greater than15, 16.5% of the time. March was his best month with a >+15 net approval over 1/3 of the time. Through April 18, Trump's net approval rating has settled back to the total period averages. The mean net approval rating for April is 13.5%, but has been declining since the end of the first week. There are no economic releases between now and the end of the month that would likely change the board much (LEI on the 20th and GDP too late to make a diff on the 28th) so barring any major announcements or unforced errors by the administration the most likely scenario by far is a net approval rating "between the 15's," although there is a Russian roulette, 1in 6 chance, he ends up with a net approval rating above 15.

"A Quinnipiac survey released today found Mr. Trump’s job approval rating among American voters at 40%, while 56% said they do not approve. Forty-one percent of Americans in a Gallup survey released Tuesday said they approve of the job the president is doing, but 52 percent said they disapprove – a net disapproval of 11 percent." http://www.cbsnews.com/news/president-trump-approval-rating-still-underwater-polls-show/
Well, the numbers are drifting deeper into the middle bucket. But the fight accompanying possible government shutdown on the 28th may take its toll.

So far the average for the 3rd month of Trump's presidency (3/24/17 - 4/19/17) is below -15, but it's undeniable that his numbers have been ticking upwards for the last few weeks. Hard to say whether this is a temporary bump up or a more permanent trend, but time is short enough that it may not matter.
He's now at -11%, which puts him safely in the middle range.

Trump isn't making this easy.  It's like he's watching this competition and relishing making our task hard by bouncing back and forth across the -15% boundary! Bannon appears to have lost his influence.  We are in a transition period between the base that elected Trump and a more traditionally oriented group of supporters.  This group just isn't very large, but it appears to be stabilizing on the plus side of -15%, so I have slightly adjusted my numbers.

Continues to seemingly greatly depend on the pace and timing of various investigations -- what they may turn up, and then what they might release to the public about any new facts and situations. Some recent news reports and analyses below seem to be useful OSINT. “Prediction prof: Trump will be impeached,” Politico, April 13, http://www.politico.com/story/2017/04/trump-impeachment-professor-allan-lichtman-237181 “Why some national-security experts say Kremlin-gate will lead to Donald Trump's impeachment,” The Oregonian, April 17, http://www.oregonlive.com/today/index.ssf/2017/04/why_national-security_speciali.html “How Ex-Spy Christopher Steele Compiled His Explosive Trump-Russia Dossier,” Vanity Fair, April edition, http://www.vanityfair.com/news/2017/03/how-the-explosive-russian-dossier-was-compiled-christopher-steele “Russian Spies' Go-To Tactics For Entangling People: Bribery And Blackmail,” National Public Radio, April 11, http://www.npr.org/sections/parallels/2017/04/11/523416914/russian-spies-go-to-tactics-for-entangling-people-bribery-and-blackmail
When Congress returns next week, Washington will be thrown into full shutdown mode. The government shuts down a week from Friday.  That will not help Trump's approval rating.
It's a net -12 today in the Gallup poll and 538 trend lines are converging.
(no change) Spicer in a bunny suit and photos of happy kids tomorrow might turn things around ;-)
Momentum has shifted in his favor. Unless there is a bombshell negative report that is lurking somewhere there should'nt be much deviations from where we are now.

The Syrian and Korean elements do not seem to have an important effect. There is a slight upturn in the polls with 7 days in the period 08.04 to 15.04 (8 days) in which the net approval rate was in the [-15,+15] interval, and only 1 day (April 14th) with a rating lower than -15. But it's very close to the border line, so it could really change on the last day.

There are too many people who will never be won over by Pres. Trump for +15. He probably stays above -15 unless the Russian ties become substantiated. His base doesn't seem to be affected by the recent failure to stick to campaign promises yet.
Wow, riding the razors edge.... back below -15 again!
Today, -16. Is it froggies? newly-minted liberals? others? who are widening the increase in the approval/disapproval gap?

Expected "rally round the flag effect" after muscle-flexing, nope, nothing. Extremely surprising. Is the base flipping with all those u-turns, growing approval from one side countered by loss in loyal base? As @Resonancia mentioned here - it looks like DT is doing better, but this does not channel into ratings. So this "better" must be "worse" for someone. DT has been quite modest lately, will we see it continuing for next 2 weeks? Hardly. Are there any easy points on the table for grab? Don't think so. There should be several skeletons still in the closet and it seems likely something jumps out in coming weeks.

Updating from 35/65/0. I thought the MOAB in Afghanistan would drive approval up but if there was any reaction, it seems to have been small and negative. The AHCA thing seems to have set a new "normal" for Trump; before that he hovered around -9 to -11, after that it's mostly -13 to -18, which of course maddeningly straddles the cutoff line.

The April 28 deadline for this GJ question is in a couple of weeks, so all the details of the U.S. counterintelligence investigations into Russian operations may not emerge by then. However, Trump's approval rating could be affected further over the Russian intelligence situation before April 28. Adjusting the below -15 share upward a bit, since international events have been more prominent in news cycles for the past week, it seems like there's less chance for persuadable opinion to substantially shift from the current trend line.

-15 today. I'm shocked because it seems to me that Trump is doing better now. OTOH, perhaps some former Trump supporters, perhaps little green frogs afraid of getting drafted, are tilting unfavorables higher. http://radar-watch.tumblr.com/post/119673245396/quickhoney-pepe-icon-beta

For every loss of support on the alt right T is gaining an offset amount of support from the establishment republicans and I expect no improvements in his standings with the left. Getting close! Very exciting. Old post:
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/445710
Again, he falls in the range for an entire week.  So, if he continues this way, he should still stay in this range.

Interesting to note that the standard deviation for the past 9 days is about a third of the standard deviation  since the beginning of the poll. In the past week Trump has shifted to more standard Republican positions. Wondering if this is stabilising his poll numbers. If so then the middle band is the most likely forecast.

Killing people is always good for the polls. http://www.cnn.com/2017/04/13/politics/trump-today-live-updates?lf-content=191183814:lb-post-3ece5eaa1a7e533991079aba04bf7a61@livefyre.com&hubRefSrc=permalink

I suspect that his support will wane, but unless he gets the ACA replaced with something that address inequity in Insurance Industry, which in turn delays his assault on the tax structure, malaise will return , turning down the temperature on his support apparatus.
3-day is -11 today (41/52) and has risen slightly over the last couple of days.

Some reversion to the mean appears to be underway. As well, perhaps we can look at reaction to President Trump's Syrian strike as sowing some confusion in the minds of his more vitriolic critics.  Their instinctive response should on the face of it have been to brand him as a hot- headed lunatic. But this didn't happen partly because the strike has undermined their narrative of the President as Russian lap dog. This distraction and the Supreme Court nomination should cause his critics to reflect and regroup before resuming their attempt to end his presidency. I think his numbers should hold between -5 and -12.

(below down 20). Today the net rating is at -11. Either a delayed reflection of Gorsuch/Syria, or an approval of the tough line against Syria and Russia. Normally, I would wait for at least one more day before adjusting, but given the few remaining days left, I am going for 50/50 now (my second scenario from yesterday).

Only a slight change from the initial forecast. The slight bump from 84% to 86% for the probability of between -15 and +15 inclusive is due to the 2 percentage point increase in the number of days the net approval rating has been between - 15 and +15. Trump's approval rating has ranged between 52% and 54%, disapproval between 40% and 41%, for the last week inclusive of the Tomahawk strike and the most recent employment data.
He's still in the middle range, but just barely.  There is still a chance it could drop or raise, but the Syria bombing seemed to have no effect on his approval rating.

Currently at -14

Today's net approval rating is -14 again, and  - as it is the average of interviews done Saturday through Monday - is supposed to fully reflect the effects of Gorsuch/Syria attack. Two hypotheses: (1) The Gorsuch/Syria events have helped Trump - the rating would have been more negative otherwise. This means that as these events fade from public memory, Trump's net rating will drop to below -15, barring new shocks. Let's say this results in 90/10 split in favor of "below -15" (2) The events have not helped Trump on net, as he may have gained and lost about the same number of voters. If this is the case, the April 28 rating is a toin coss - 50/50 between the two buckets (as at -14 now it is very close to the dividing line).  Assigning the equal probability of 50% to hypotheses (1) and (2), I arrive at 70 percent for the "below -15" bucket. Note that this may be slightly conservative, as conventional wisdom holds that Gorsuch/Syria should have helped, meaning that hypothesis (1) may be slightly more likely. Without too much research, here's how I see this:  Overall, I think the tenor of news coverage (in the aggregate) is what drives the fundamentals of this question. 1. Partisans on both sides are fairly predictable, and the only way you get a +15 is if an outside force scrambles the calculus of "the resistance." (akin to the national response to 9/11 sending GWB's approval sky-high) So that one is as likely as a world-changing event, which I'm pegging at 5%.  2. This means that 95% of the time, the less ideological bloc will determine which way net approval goes.  I think this bloc primarily responds to the "mood music" of the Trump admin media coverage.  I define the mood music as 1. what mainstream news covers, 1a. how they choose to frame it, 2. conservative media's counter-framing effort to bend the narrative for their own ends. (Note: I'm not saying msm is liberal. There is no left equivalent to conservative political/media/lobbying network) 3. My guess on the mood music is that Trump is due for a minor net corrective uptick over the next few weeks because 
- the story on Russia, wiretapping, and congress is getting complicated
- the logical "plot twist" would be in the direction of a surprising shift, like "Trump is learning how to be President," similar to what happened in the immediate wake of speech to congress in late Feb. I have no idea what the hook for this slow turn could be (a hook may not even be needed), but my sense is the mainstream's vigor re incremental updates to the Russia story will wane a bit.  The short-term counterframe of  "see this was all overblown from the start," would gain some attention by filling the vacuum, and the overall mood music would get a little less dire for Trump. Since he's at -18 as of this writing, I would say shifting back into the -15 to +15 range is worth 60% of my remaining 95%. 4. I do think there's a chance for events to intervene and advance the plot in the other direction - something like a senior staff resignation, another weird tweeting jag, or a real revelation by the FBI would probably do it. This would satisfy the media's collective desire for a "plot twist," no matter that it wouldn't be in the "Trump is getting better/settling down" direction. The counter-frame would continue to strain for credibility since real-world events have to at least be acknowledged, and there's no persuasive way for the fox/breitbart apparatus to address events like these in a way that will move the needle . So in a normal world this would be rarer, but with the recent history of this high-variance administration, I think it's good for my remaining 35%.

Below are dates when the net approval moved < 3 % either way and the probable event that triggered it: 26 Jan: -4 % --> 2 executive orders (The Wall, deportation)
27 Jan: -5 %  --> Travel ban fallout
16 Feb: -4 % --> Secretary of labour withdrawal
17 Feb: +3 % --> First Trump press conference during presidency
19 Feb +3 % --> Rally in Orlando
28 Feb +3 % --> Secretary of commerce confirmation
10 Mar: +5 % --> Positive jobs report
12 Mar: -5 % --> Judge rules against 2nd travel ban
13 Mar: -7 % --> Flynn resigns over talks with Russians
15 Mar +3 % --> Tax return leak
18 Mar -6 % --> Meeting with Merkel
19 Mar +5 % --> Meeting with Merkel fallout
23 Mar +4 % --> Nunes confirms "incidental" wire tap of Trump tower
26 Mar -7 % --> Healthcare bill fails in congress
28 Mar -4 % --> Obama climate change policies overturned The conclusion is pretty obvious: rallies and acting like candidate Trump work for his base and revive his support coupled with good economic news. Failure to implement policies, and other embarrassments for the administration erode the approval. Looking ahead, April is full of tough and pivotal negotiations in congress to get the budget passed and avoiding the debt ceiling and possible government shutdown. There is also a vote on Trump's nominee for the supreme court. The main economic news will be the jobs report for March, released in the first half of April. Conclusion: The Democrats will fight hard against the budget and the Gorsuch appointment, but a shutdown is unlikely. Ultimately just getting things done could boost Trump's support, but on the other hand he has other tricky policies on his agenda, such as tax reform. In the end I just don't see enough positives for him to drag himself back from -24 %.

Trump is unlikely to obtain funding for the Wall this year, failing to meet another campaign promise.  If a government shut-down occurs on April 28th, his approval rating will plummet by 15 points or more.  If one is avoided and a budget is passed, it's likely that whatever is in it will be highly unpopular to one or both parties and among the general population, resulting in a fall within 15 points.   There's also a slim possibility that something devastation will occur resulting in a rally round the flag effect that will lead to a soaring approval rating.  I put this at a 1% possibility.  Largely, I do not anticipate his approval rating increasing at all by April 28th, the question is mostly how low will it go?

Moving my forecast slightly in the below -15 direction on Trump matching his record -21 net approval rating today. 2/3rds of the forecasting period is now essentially over and we have about as much useful historical data on Trump as we are likely to get.  http://www.gallup.com/poll/201617/gallup-daily-trump-job-approval.aspx As expected, Trump's approval numbers have trended consistently lower as time has passed, in line with the performance of historical presidential approval numbers. Trump's monthly average net approval rating has worsened by over 2 full points when comparing his first month in office to his second (-9.3 vs. -11.4). These numbers worsen by ~40bps when the results from the last 3 days are included in the second month average.   A VERY cursory and superficial analysis using Trump's approval numbers over the past two months and Excel's forecast function implies a net approval rating of -20 by April 28th. Granted, reality (and people) are not quite so easy to model, but it's worth noting that the trend is strongly negative and accelerating.  It is still possible that Trump will turn things around - perhaps through a resounding success in tax reform, or a complete dismissal of Russian collaboration allegations by enforcement agencies - but it does seem unlikely. Any sort of reversal in the current trend will likely have to be a result of an unexpected catalyst - some unforeseen event that changes the current paradigm.  I expect we will continue to see more of the same instead.

I've taken the past 57 values and fitted a trend line. This forecasts a -19% by April 28th. I then calculated the standard deviation and used the forecast value as a mean to calculate a Z-score for my present prediction. Today's testimonies can't be good for Trump. Comey did not say "no evidence for coordination between the campaign and the Russians", and he and Rogers flatly denied wiretapping Trump Tower. But Trump's support has a floor (probably at 35-37) and disapproval has a ceiling (60?). So while below -15 is possible, it's not that overwhelming, and future events can move the needle back above -15.  Assuming a range of 35-42 for Trump's support and 52-60 for disapproval (based on recent ratings), and an uniform distribution within these ranges yields a range of (-10, -25) for the net approval, and a probability of 60% of falling below -15. So this is my guess for now, until new events change this math.

Drawing from Lichtman’s book, Predicting the Next President, 13 keys determine the popular vote.  While popular vote is not necessarily the same as net approval rating, I’ll note that Trump’s -8% (46% - 54%) popular vote margin mimics his recent negative net approval ratings after discounting for the election and inaugural bumps.  So, I am going to say they are similar enough.   Aspects of the keys relevant to the timeframe of this question are short-term economy, social unrest, scandal, foreign/military failures and successes, party performance and policy change.  Relative to these keys, what will be different between now and April 28th that will alter Trump’s current -6% net approval rating?   Some keys will stay the same.  The positive direction of the economy and the current level of social unease are likely to continue.  Given the ethical conflicts within the Trump Administration, issues related to Russia, and the nature of the President himself, continuing hints of scandal are inevitable, but the bar here is high.  A true scandal, if there ever is one, will likely take longer than April 28th to manifest itself in the public’s mind.   The prospects for foreign/military failures and successes within the next 51 days are probably balanced. Two keys will probably improve as the new Congress gets rolling and looks ahead to the midterms.  Republicans are likely to take legislative actions that will implement policy changes, and regardless of an individual’s politics, getting something done in Washington DC will cast a positive light on Trump. On balance then, Trump’s net approval rating is likely to improve from here.  However, looking at Gallup’s historical Presidential Job Approval data, approval ratings do not improve very fast without a cataclysmic event ( e.g., 911).  I’ll go with a 5/90/5 score for now.

Reaffirming my forecast with Trump at -18 today: http://www.gallup.com/poll/201617/gallup-daily-trump-job-approval.aspx There appears to be no structural reason preventing Trump from a -15 approval rating. The questions that remain for me are as follows: - While presidential approval ratings tend to be highest immediately following inauguration before trending downwards, Trump has had an unusual start plagued by outrage, protest, and scandal. Is his current approval rating an outlier that will trend back towards his "mean" as the population becomes desensitized / stops paying attention? - Is Trump capable of moderating his behavior in such a way as to turn public perception? It seems unlikely - the pundits have been predicting his upcoming pivot to the center for almost a year at this point. That being said, he IS a master marketer, so perhaps he will find a way to sell himself better to the American public. - What is the likelihood of a major national emergency that might unite the public behind him? Without going back and actually checking the history books, the odds of this seem low. I'd say an event like this typically occurs once a presidency, if at all. Looking at the first year of presidential terms from historic Gallup polls [1] shows that there is very commonly a drop in positive sentiment for a president after his inauguration.  There is a 'honeymoon' period. Trump is starting from an historic low net approval rating [2] and is unlikely to improve. I believe the dynamics are that his opponents will remain opposed, and his supporters will begin to be frustrated by the methods used by the administration. Supporters, I believe, will become negative even if he does everything he promised. I assert this because it seems easier to be frustrated with the 'how' of a policy implementation than it is to support that it has been done. The logical conclusion is that there will be more negativity than positivity. [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_presidential_approval_rating
[2] http://www.gallup.com/poll/201617/gallup-daily-trump-job-approval.aspx EDIT: Just discovered that the honeymoon effect is a known political science term that refers to the ability to pass legislation. I do not use that interpretation! I am just talking about positive opinion from the public, not the legislature.

I made major changes in my original forecast because I couldn’t reconcile two sets of data. First, during the campaign his favorable rating ranged from 32 to 45 and his unfavorable, from 48 to 63, with the last Gallup poll for January 4-8 being 40 favorable/ 55 unfavorable. Second his initial net job approval from Gallup started at 0 and then rose to +1.  I remembered a CNN article I read a little after the election, http://www.cnn.com/2016/11/11/politics/hillary-clinton-donald-trump-voters-dislike/. It indicates that there were 18 million voters who felt both candidates were unfit to be president and of these 69% voted for Trump. I draw two conclusions from this. First, it explains the discrepancy between his favorability polls with his initial job approval numbers. There are 12 million people who have an unfavorable view of Trump but nonetheless voted for him. These people are in a state of cognitive dissonance, thinking that if they voted for Trump he can’t be that bad a president.  Second, his initial job approval numbers are soft, and they can regress to his prior unfavorable numbers.  Clearly, this can already be seen in the results of the past few days. I think the numbers can easily approach -15% in the next couple of months, but unclear if it goes past that. So it’s 50/50 for the moment and a 2% for +15 just because the numbers are volatile and I really don’t know what’s going to happen.

(Below up 5). Trump's approval rating is evolving in a historically unprecedented way. No president has had a net approval of -9 after a week. I see two possibilities from here:  - once his cabinet members are in office (in particular Tillerson and Ross), they will exercise some moderating effect on the White House. So policy making will become more deliberate, with an effort to minimize the negative side effects. This should lead to some stabilization of Trump's net approval rating in the (-15, 0) range (support 40-45, disapproval 45-55);  - the White House remains bent on delivering Trump's promises, all critics be damned. This would lead to independents taking a definite anti-Trump view, and support dropping to the core (which I still estimate at about 40% for the first 100 days). Then Trump's net approval rating will stay in the (-20, -10) range. I place a higher probability on the first scenario (60-40), since in the second one Trump would likely lose his ability to govern, with some clear opposition from the Republicans in the Senate. And even in the second scenario he may end up above -15. Hence the 80-20 split.

There was some number crunching that went into this.  First, it is important to note the popular vote as a way to gauge where Trump started off in terms of popularity.  It can be assumed that on election day, roughly all 62 million Trump voters would have said they approve of him as a president.  So, this would put Trump at a 48.8% approval rating.  Between now and then, his rating has sunk down to 45%.  Of the remaining population, 45% disapprove and 10% are undecided.  Based off of his antics, stances on divisive issues and overall presence, it is unlikely Trump will convince those who already dislike him, to begin to approve of him as a president.  However, it is not entirely impossible, which is why there is a 5% chance that Trump will have a +15 net approval.  Of those who are undecided, there are a few possibilities.  I expect there to be three potential splits - 7% approve and 3% disapprove, 5% approve and 5% disapprove, 3% approve and 7% disapprove.  My best guess is that the last option is most likely.  The nation mostly belongs to the Democratic party, and Trump doesn't do himself any favors by staying out of the spotlight.  So, with the undecided population now decided, the split comes out to a 52% disapprove, 48% approve.  This is a net of -4%.  This gap could further widen to a 57% disapprove and 43% approve split with a margin of -14%.  In other words, Trump would need to lose the support of 3,148,994 people which is roughly the population of Iowa.  This is not people that already dislike him - Trump would need to under perform so badly that 3 million of his own supporters would feel the need to reject him.  That is a substantial amount, and not one to be taken lightly.  However, the political landscape is becoming a minefield.  Trump is going to oversee the repealing of Obamacare and sign its replacement into law.  In order to live up to campaign promises, it will have to be nothing short of stellar.  Speaking of campaign promises, that list has yet to be touched, which could make his voting base start to feel resentful.  These factors could play into a substantial loss of support for Trump.  As such, this is why I have put the final split of odds for Trump at a 25% chance he has a net approval of -15, 70% that he has a net of -15 to +15 (inclusive), and 5% that he has a net of +15.

Update of arithmetics:
 - approval range: 40-50 percent (from 35-50). His activism will keep his supporters happy in the first 100 days.
 - disapproval range: 40-55 percent (from 45-60). Shifting the range based on recently observed values. So his best result is now  +10 (50-40), while his worst is -15 (40-55). This lies entirely within the -15 to +15 range, but I leave some 15 percent for the possibility of being wrong on the downside. (Being wrong on the upside is not too costly, as there is some room from my best +10 result to the edge of the +15 range).

My simple arithmetics:
 - Trump has both a hard ceiling and a hard floor for his approval rating, (at least the first 100 days). As he has been so controversial from the start, I assuming he is now  in the middle of this range, which places the ceiling at 50% and the floor - at 35%.
 - Similarly, his disapproval would range (I think) between 45 and 60% in the next 100 days.
 - Finally, Gallup's methodology does allow undecided (see Obama's Jan 19 ratings: 59-37 approval/disapproval, which don't sum to 100%). I assume Trump's undecided will not exceed 5% as he is so polarizing.  This means Trump's best result would be +5 (50% approval, 45% disapproval, 5 undecided), and his worst result -25 (35% approval, 60 disapproval, 5 neutral). Assuming the result on April 28 can be anywhere in this range, this gives about 1/3 chance of below -15 and 2/3 for the -15 to +15 bucket. Can't wait to check this against actual Gallup poll data when such come along.

Trump's net approval rating currently sits at -13 by the question's definition [1]. I have heard, and confirmed by checking the Obama, Bush Jr & Clinton numbers [2,3], and it makes some kind of sense to me, that most president's approval ratings fall right after they take office. During the campaign people idolize candidates, and then reality settles in and everyone is inevitably disappointed. On the other hand, I'm not sure if what's happening is better described as "approval ratings DECREASE" or "approval ratings REGRESS TO THE MEAN". If the latter, one would expect to see Trump's net approval ratings go back towards zero. Trump was vilified throughout his campaign, so it is possible that once boring reality sets in, people are less inflamed and move from "disapprove" to "no opinion" (so in answer to the survey question --- which does not offer a neutral option --- they would be equally likely to say either). So I will make a judgement call here, since apparently we have NEVER had a president start off with NEGATIVE approval ratings. Indeed roughly speaking they all start with 60s-70s approval ratings [3], with the very strange outlier of Eisenhower, which is so strange that I suspect an error in data collection or data entry. (His approval rating shoots up from 30% to 70% in one month?) As the unprecedented Women's March and general media treatment illustrate, I believe the people who disapprove of Trump will not stop disapproving of him. It seems to be a strong identity issue, moreso than usual. Moreover his cabinet picks don't seem even slightly conciliatory. If that's right, it mathematically caps his net approval at 45 - 55 = -10. For it to go above 15 he would need at least 57.5% approval, i.e. for 23% of the people who currently disapprove of him to switch to approving, in about 3 months. It simply won't happen. On the other hand, of the 42% who currently approve of Trump, if just 10% switch from "approve" to "no opinion", (and assuming no-opinioners answer approve/disapprove randomly) that would bring the net approval to below -15. Of course it's unrealistic to assume that NOBODY who currently disapproves of Trump will stop doing so. So let me approach the question in a more nuanced manner. Suppose x% of Trump-unfavorable people become Trump-favorable, and y% of Trump-fav become Trump-unfav, between now and 28 April 2017. What relationship between x and y would make Trump net approval dip below -15? Working out the arithmetic we find y > 1.31x + 2.38 In other words, if 5% of Trump-unfav become Trump-fav, we'd still get net approval below -15 if ~9% of Trump-fav became Trump-unfav. I'm not sure how likely this is for various values of x, nor what the most likely values of x are. It is some question of elasticity if you will; are Trump-favs more than ~1.5 times as likely to flip as Trump-unfavs? Put that way it seems very likely to me. The narrative is that Trump won as an outsider because people hated insiders, and now he will become more like an insider. On the other hand, approval ratings jump around quite a bit in response to big actions of the president, and 28 April may happen to fall in the aftermath of some big Trump decision, like banning immigration as per another question. For now I will say 75% chance of below -15, but this is a question where frequent updating will be key. [1] http://www.gallup.com/poll/199997/trump-maintains-post-election-bounce-no-new-gains.aspx
[2] http://www.gallup.com/poll/113980/gallup-daily-obama-job-approval.aspx
[3] http://www.gallup.com/poll/116677/presidential-approval-ratings-gallup-historical-statistics-trends.aspx
[4] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwight_D._Eisenhower#Early_life_and_education

I don't have any confidence in how this works. Both Trump and Clinton had historically high disapproval ratings headed into the election. I assume about a third (let's say 35% to more easily conceptualize this question though I have no idea about the accuracy of either assumption) of the U.S. population is partisan enough to approve & same amount to disapprove of a candidate based solely on the candidate's affiliation with a party they like (or unaffiliation with the party they can't stand). So assume 30% of the population remain open to changing opinion. Plus-or-minus 15% means about 3 times as many of those people who were open to changing opinion did so for the better or worse even though they had no strong feeling beforehand. I've weighted more toward "minus" because more than 50% of people disapproved of both candidates headed into the polls and 100 days is a short period of time to turn that perception around. I welcome people's corrections of the above assumptions and logic... they have no basis in fact necessarily (note no research /cites went into this)
